--- title: "Lecture [11a] Activity" --- ![](../../img/programmer_2780E3.svg){.hero} ## Question 1 Examine the `table5` tibble (included in \{tidyverse\}) and tidy it up using `separate()` and `unite()`. End with variables for country, four-digit year (YYYY), number of tuberculosis cases, and population.

Click here for the answer key
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) table5 |> unite( col = "year", century, year, sep = "" ) |> separate_wider_delim( col = rate, delim = "/", names = c("cases", "population") ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 4 country year cases population 1 Afghanistan 1999 745 19987071 2 Afghanistan 2000 2666 20595360 3 Brazil 1999 37737 172006362 4 Brazil 2000 80488 174504898 5 China 1999 212258 1272915272 6 China 2000 213766 1280428583 ``` ::: :::

## Question 2 Reshape the `billboard` tibble (included in \{tidyverse\}) to a long format such that each row represents a single track’s ranking for a single week (variables: `artist`, `track`, `date.entered`, `week`, `rank`). For a challenge, remove the prefix from your final week variable and convert it into a numeric variable.

Click here for the answer key
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} billboard |> pivot_longer( cols = starts_with("wk"), names_to = "week", values_to = "rank", names_prefix = "wk", # Challenge names_transform = parse_number # Challenge ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 24,092 × 5 artist track date.entered week rank 1 2 Pac Baby Don't Cry (Keep... 2000-02-26 1 87 2 2 Pac Baby Don't Cry (Keep... 2000-02-26 2 82 3 2 Pac Baby Don't Cry (Keep... 2000-02-26 3 72 4 2 Pac Baby Don't Cry (Keep... 2000-02-26 4 77 5 2 Pac Baby Don't Cry (Keep... 2000-02-26 5 87 6 2 Pac Baby Don't Cry (Keep... 2000-02-26 6 94 7 2 Pac Baby Don't Cry (Keep... 2000-02-26 7 99 8 2 Pac Baby Don't Cry (Keep... 2000-02-26 8 NA 9 2 Pac Baby Don't Cry (Keep... 2000-02-26 9 NA 10 2 Pac Baby Don't Cry (Keep... 2000-02-26 10 NA # ℹ 24,082 more rows ``` ::: :::

## Question 3 Reshape the `table2` tibble (included in \{tidyverse\}) so that each row represents a single country in a single year (Hint: variables should be `country`, `year`, `cases`, and `population`).

Click here for the answer key
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} table2 |> pivot_wider(names_from = type, values_from = count) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 4 country year cases population 1 Afghanistan 1999 745 19987071 2 Afghanistan 2000 2666 20595360 3 Brazil 1999 37737 172006362 4 Brazil 2000 80488 174504898 5 China 1999 212258 1272915272 6 China 2000 213766 1280428583 ``` ::: :::

## Optional Challenge Reshape the `us_rent_income` tibble (included in \{tidyverse\}) so that each row represents a single US state (Hint: Variables should be something like: `GEOID`, `NAME`, `estimate_income`, `estimate_rent`, `moe_income`, and `moe_rent`)

Click here for the answer key
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} us_rent_income |> pivot_wider( names_from = variable, values_from = c(estimate, moe) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 52 × 6 GEOID NAME estimate_income estimate_rent moe_income moe_rent 1 01 Alabama 24476 747 136 3 2 02 Alaska 32940 1200 508 13 3 04 Arizona 27517 972 148 4 4 05 Arkansas 23789 709 165 5 5 06 California 29454 1358 109 3 6 08 Colorado 32401 1125 109 5 7 09 Connecticut 35326 1123 195 5 8 10 Delaware 31560 1076 247 10 9 11 District of Columbia 43198 1424 681 17 10 12 Florida 25952 1077 70 3 # ℹ 42 more rows ``` ::: :::

--- *Note that there is no need to turn in Activities. These are just for practice!*
